extra_unstructured_rules.topic: Intermediary liability in direct marketing chains
extra_unstructured_rules.text: When a controller obtains personal data through a chain of intermediaries (e.g., retailer → media agency → data broker → commercial data provider), the controller remains fully liable for GDPR compliance. Relying on intermediaries' compliance is not sufficient to exempt the controller from liability.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Complex multi-party scenario with specific liability allocation not covered by standard template fields

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Direct marketing now encompasses all activities undertaken to communicate solicited or unsolicited promotional messages, including preparatory processing steps such as profiling before sending targeted advertising messages. This includes audience profiling, segmentation, automated decision-making (e.g., dynamic pricing algorithms), and mixed-content communications combining informational and promotional content.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Broad definitional change affecting scope of compliance; multiple examples provided

extra_unstructured_rules.topic: Data subject rights in direct marketing
extra_unstructured_rules.text: Individuals whose personal data is processed for direct marketing have significant privacy rights. When exercising rights of restriction of processing or erasure, controllers must notify all recipients in the direct marketing scheme (e.g., other participants) of erasure requests.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Multi-party notification obligation specific to direct marketing context

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Current regime: Opt-out system applies; telemarketing calls permitted unless recipient has objected or registered on 'Do Not Call Me' list. Proposed regime: Opt-in system; telemarketing calls to natural persons only permitted with explicit prior consent. Legislative proposal under discussion in House of Representatives; BDPA issued opinion on 9 April 2025.

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Digital services and marketing platforms must comply with accessibility requirements under the Law on Accessibility Requirements for Products and Services (effective June 28, 2025). Exceptions include pre-recorded time-based media content published before June 28, 2025, online maps (if essential information available elsewhere), archived digital material not updated after June 28, 2025, and services by micro-enterprises. All digital service providers must publish accessibility statements detailing compliance, known shortcomings, remediation measures, and user reporting mechanisms.

legal_restrictions.description: PIPA provides individuals with a right to submit a written request to an organization to cease or not begin using their personal information for advertising, marketing, or public relations purposes.

special_requirements: Intermediaries and e-commerce service providers must use personal data only for internal marketing, billing, or other purposes necessary for service provision, or purposes made known to the customer prior to collection, or with prior consent.

Marketing communications (telephone, SMS, email, electronic communications) from outside Bermuda to Bermuda persons are permitted if instigated by a Bermuda person (reverse inquiry basis) and the overseas company does not establish a presence in Bermuda.
Organizations must provide written reasons if they refuse a request to cease marketing communications.

max_fine.notes: PIPA violations: individuals liable to fine up to $25,000 or up to two years imprisonment; entities liable to fine not exceeding $250,000 on indictment. ETA Standard violations: $5,000 per day of contravention after written warning.

sources.recent_changes: Data Protection Act 2024 came into effect on 14 January 2025, replacing the Data Protection Act 32 of 2018. The new Act strengthens data protection framework, aligns with international standards (GDPR-like), and introduces significantly higher penalties for non-compliance.

extra_unstructured_rules.text: The Data Protection Act 2024 establishes a comprehensive framework for personal data protection in Botswana. The Information and Data Protection Commission (IDPC) is the national supervisory authority responsible for ensuring effective application and compliance. The Act addresses modern challenges including cross-border data transfers and data breaches, and provides individuals with robust rights including access, correction, and erasure of personal data.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Foundational regulatory framework that applies broadly to all telemarketing activities involving personal data; not specific to individual compliance elements.
extra_unstructured_rules.source: Data Protection Act 2024; BoardCloud and Michalsons sources

extra_unstructured_rules.text: BOCRA's Consumer Protection Policy (December 2024) requires service providers to maintain call centers or toll-free numbers for consumer complaints at no charge, issue clear and accurate itemized bills on time, send bundle usage depletion notifications via SMS at 50%, 80%, and 100% usage levels, and maintain quarterly complaint records submitted to the Authority. Service providers must not auto-renew services upon contract termination.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Specific operational requirements for communications service providers that may apply to telemarketing operations; encompasses multiple compliance elements not easily categorized into single fields.
extra_unstructured_rules.source: Consumer Protection Policy - Communications Sector (BOCRA, December 2024)

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Non-compliance with the Data Protection Act 2024 may result in substantial fines up to BWP 50,000,000 or 4% of global annual turnover (whichever is higher), imprisonment for serious offenses, or both. The Act significantly raises maximum administrative fines compared to previous legislation, underscoring the seriousness of data protection compliance in Botswana.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Enforcement information already partially captured in enforcement section, but additional context on severity and dual penalties (fines + imprisonment) warrants separate documentation.
extra_unstructured_rules.source: Data Protection Act 2024; BoardCloud and Michalsons sources

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Multiple authorities oversee compliance: (1) Information and Data Protection Commission (IDPC) - enforces Data Protection Act 2024; (2) Botswana Communications Regulatory Authority (BOCRA) - regulates telecommunications, broadcasting, postal services, and enforces consumer protection in communications sector; (3) Competition and Consumer Authority (CCA) - enforces competition and consumer protection laws generally.

legal_restrictions.description: Subscriber or addressee has the right to demand stopping of advertisement distribution. Advertiser must immediately stop advertising upon demand within one working day from receiving the demand.
Distribution of advertisements by telecommunication means (telephone, telex, facsimile, mobile telephone communications, email) can only be performed with prior consent of subscriber or addressee.
Consent can be made as a text document, including document in electronic form, or as part of an agreement for telecom services.

When consent is part of a telecom services agreement, subscriber or addressee must be informed about their right to demand stopping advertisement distribution, which shall be specifically confirmed by the subscriber.

special_requirements: Consent can be included as part of a telecom services agreement, but subscriber must be explicitly informed of their right to opt-out and must specifically confirm this right.

Personal data protection is governed by Law on Personal Data Protection No. 99-Z (effective 15 November 2021), which includes breach notification requirements to the National Personal Data Protection Center (NPDPC) within three working days of discovery.
Use of names, pseudonyms, images or statements of citizens without consent is prohibited in advertising.

Distribution of audio/video recordings or photos of individuals without consent is allowed only if measures are taken to prevent identification and if dissemination does not violate constitutional rights and is necessary to protect public interests.

rules.exceptions: Individuals whose rights have been violated as a result of creation and/or distribution of an advertisement are entitled to protect their rights in court proceedings.

max_fine.notes: No specific fine amounts found in available sources for Belarus telemarketing violations.

b2b.description: Regulated telemarketing regime with mandatory identification prefixes for mass communications. Distinction between solicited and unsolicited communications. Compliance with SUBTEL regulations (Resolución Exenta Nº286) mandatory since August 13, 2025.

b2c.description: Regulated telemarketing regime with mandatory identification prefixes for mass communications. Distinction between solicited and unsolicited communications. Compliance with SUBTEL regulations (Resolución Exenta Nº286) mandatory since August 13, 2025.

b2b.notes: No explicit B2B-specific relationship requirements found in available sources. Regulation distinguishes between solicited and unsolicited communications but does not specify relationship duration or type requirements.

b2c.notes: Regulation distinguishes between solicited communications (prefix 600, requires prior authorization) and unsolicited communications (prefix 809). No explicit opt-in/soft opt-in framework details found in available sources.

b2b.notes: No explicit exemption framework for existing customers found in available sources.

b2c.notes: No explicit exemption framework for existing customers found in available sources.

ai_disclosure.note:
Regulation mentions AI-generated communications as covered under mass communications definition but does not specify explicit AI disclosure requirements beyond general identification prefix requirements.
Quote requests: Chile's proposed AI regulation and new data protection law (Law 21.719) emphasize transparency and risk-based obligations for AI systems, including requirements to disclose artificial nature when interacting with humans or generating content. However, there is no explicit mention in official government sources or legal documents regarding specific exceptions for telemarketing quote requests or distinctions between existing customers and cold calls. The law mandates disclosure for AI-generated content and high-risk systems, but does not clarify whether quote requests are exempt. Therefore, the requirement for AI disclosure in telemarketing quote requests is not explicitly stated as required or exempt in current official sources.

caller_id_requirements.note: SUBTEL Resolución Exenta Nº286 mandates specific prefixes for all mass and/or automated communications. Prefix 600 for solicited communications (with prior authorization), prefix 809 for unsolicited communications. Mandatory since August 13, 2025. Non-compliance prohibited after this date.

frequency_limits.note: No explicit frequency limits found in available sources.

legal_restrictions.description: All mass and/or automated communications must use designated prefixes. Prefix 600 for solicited communications, prefix 809 for unsolicited communications.
Regulation covers all types of communications: verbal, written, pre-recorded, AI-generated, and others. Excludes emergency communications.
Regulation aims to prevent fraud and scams associated with unauthorized calls.

special_requirements: Companies must request assigned numerations within 6 months of official publication (deadline was August 13, 2025)
After compliance deadline, use of any numerations other than 600 or 809 is prohibited for mass communications
Insurance companies must ensure strict compliance and adjust agreements with call centers and advertising agencies
Users can report non-compliance to SUBTEL through official channels

rules.caller_id: Mandatory identification with prefixes 600 (solicited) or 809 (unsolicited) for all mass and automated communications
rules.exceptions: Emergency communications are excluded from prefix requirements

max_fine.notes: Fines range from 5 to 5,000 UTM per violation. As of August 2025, 1 UTM = approximately 68,647 CLP (Chilean Pesos). Maximum fine approximately 343,235,000 CLP. Companies not complying with prefix requirements face sanctions.

sources.recent_changes: Resolución Exenta Nº286 published February 13, 2025; mandatory compliance effective August 13, 2025. Modifies Resolución Exenta N°1.319/2004. Introduces mandatory prefix system (600 and 809) for mass communications.

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Solicited communications (prefix 600): Services of information and/or advertising purposes to telephone service subscribers/users through automated and/or mass communications that HAVE BEEN REQUESTED OR AUTHORIZED by the subscriber/user. Unsolicited communications (prefix 809): Services of information and/or advertising purposes through automated and/or mass communications that HAVE NOT BEEN REQUESTED OR AUTHORIZED by the subscriber/user.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Definitional framework that applies across all requirements; foundational to the entire regulatory regime

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Ley 21.719 on Personal Data Protection will enter into force in December 2026, introducing additional requirements including explicit consent for data use and economic sanctions up to 20,000 UTM per violation. This will complement current telemarketing regulations.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Future regulatory change affecting telemarketing compliance landscape; not yet in force but relevant for compliance planning
extra_unstructured_rules.source: SUBTEL and Ministry of Transport and Telecommunications announcements

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Companies had 6 months from February 13, 2025 publication (until August 13, 2025) to request assigned numerations. After August 13, 2025, use of any numerations other than 600 or 809 for mass communications is prohibited. Compliance was mandatory for all telecommunications operators and service providers.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Time-bound implementation requirement with hard deadline; critical for operational compliance

extra_unstructured_rules.text: SUBTEL will enforce compliance through monitoring and investigation. Users are encouraged to report and file complaints through SUBTEL official channels if they receive calls from companies not using the required prefixes. Non-compliance can result in warnings or fines.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Enforcement mechanism combining regulatory oversight with user reporting; important for practical compliance

b2b.description: Opt-in consent required for telemarketing calls and SMS. Companies must obtain prior express written consent before contacting businesses for marketing purposes.

b2c.description: Opt-in consent required for telemarketing calls and SMS. Companies must obtain prior express written consent before contacting consumers for marketing purposes. Governed by Consumer Rights Protection Law and Administrative Provisions on Short Message Services.

b2b.notes: Explicit consent is required for telemarketing in almost all cases. No soft opt-in mechanism identified in Chinese law.

b2c.notes: Explicit consent is required for telemarketing in almost all cases. If a user has not explicitly agreed to be contacted, it is treated as a refusal under Chinese rules.

b2b.notes: No explicit exemption for existing business customers identified in search results.

b2c.notes: No explicit exemption for existing consumers identified in search results. Consent requirements appear to apply universally.

ai_disclosure.note:
AI-powered voice bots are used in China's telemarketing industry, but no explicit disclosure requirements found in search results. General advertising law prohibits misleading statements.
Quote requests: It is not possible to complete the requested up-to-date, source-specific internet research using only official Chinese government or regulatory websites in this environment because external search tools and browsing are not available in this turn. As a result, no reliable determination can be made here about whether current PRC regulations specifically require or exempt AI disclosure for telemarketing quote‑request calls, nor about any different rules for existing customers versus cold calls.

caller_id_requirements.note: Call centers must use authorized numbers obtained from telecom operators. False Caller ID or number masking is forbidden. Anti-Telecom Fraud Law requires real caller ID transmission and blocks calls with spoofed or altered numbers.

frequency_limits.note: No specific frequency limits identified in search results.

legal_restrictions.description: Prior express written consent must be obtained before sending commercial SMS or making telemarketing calls
Companies cannot call consumers who have rejected or opted out of communications
Misleading or false statements during calls are prohibited. Impersonating government or bank officials is strictly prohibited.
95XX numbers (special 8-digit prefix for call centers) are banned for outbound marketing calls as of mid-2020
Companies cannot use phone lists without individual's informed consent or legitimate legal ground

special_requirements: White list of users must be maintained
Relevant materials and records must be retained
Time and conduct of calls must be regulated
Clear opt-out instructions required in SMS messages (typically 'Reply STOP')
SMS marketing requires clear opt-out instructions in every message
Sender identification must be included in all SMS messages

rules.caller_id: Call centers must use authorized telephone numbers obtained from telecom operators. False Caller ID or number masking is forbidden. Real caller ID transmission is required by Anti-Telecom Fraud Law.
rules.exceptions: No exceptions to caller ID requirements identified. 95XX numbers are prohibited for outbound marketing calls.

max_fine.notes: Under Consumer Rights Protection Law, companies that do not comply with consumer personal data rights can be fined up to 10 times the illegal income. If no illegal income is found, maximum fine is RMB 500,000 (approximately USD 77,000). Violations can also result in warnings, carrier termination of numbers, or criminal liability for fraud-related spoofing.

b2b.description: B2B telemarketing in Cyprus is regulated under the Radio and Television Broadcasting Stations Law 1998 (as amended) and the Regulation of Electronic Communications and Postal Services Law 112(I)/2004. The regime requires prior consent for automated calling systems and electronic communications used for direct marketing purposes.

b2c.description: B2C telemarketing in Cyprus is regulated under the Radio and Television Broadcasting Stations Law 1998 (as amended), the Regulation of Electronic Communications and Postal Services Law 112(I)/2004, and the Consumer Protection Law 2021. The regime requires prior consent for direct marketing via electronic communications. Additional restrictions apply to specific product categories (pharmaceuticals, alcoholic beverages).

b2b.notes: Automated calling and communications systems without human intervention, fax and electronic mail may be used for direct marketing purposes only where a subscriber who is a natural person has consented to such use in advance. No explicit soft opt-in exemption found for B2B in search results.

b2c.notes: Prior consent required for SMS and email marketing. Soft opt-in allowed for existing customers with clear opt-out mechanism (e.g., 'Reply STOP' for SMS, unsubscribe link for emails).

b2b.notes: No explicit exemption for existing B2B customers found in search results.

exemption_conditions: Customer must be existing customer
Marketing must be for related products or services
Clear opt-out mechanism must be provided
b2c.notes: Soft opt-in exemption available for existing customers. Opt-out mechanism must be clear and functional (e.g., 'STOP' reply for SMS).

retention.notes: No explicit recording requirements or restrictions found in search results for telemarketing calls.

ai_disclosure.note:
No explicit AI disclosure requirements found in search results for Cyprus telemarketing. General transparency principles may apply under GDPR and consumer protection law.
Quote requests: It is not possible to complete the requested internet search using only official Cypriot government and regulatory sources in this environment because external search and browsing tools cannot be accessed in this turn. As a result, no clear, current, and authoritative statement can be made about whether Cyprus specifically requires or exempts AI disclosure for telemarketing calls whose purpose is a quote request, nor whether rules differ for existing customers versus cold calls. For up-to-date and authoritative information, it is necessary to consult directly the websites and legal databases of the Republic of Cyprus (e.g., legislation portals and competent authorities) and relevant EU law (including the EU Artificial Intelligence Act and applicable personal data and electronic communications rules) or obtain local legal advice.

exceptions: Telemarketing messages are prohibited during children's programmes under Radio and Television Broadcasting Stations Law 1998 (as amended)

caller_id_requirements.note: No explicit caller ID requirements found in search results. General transparency principles apply under GDPR and consumer protection law.

frequency_limits.note: No explicit frequency limits found in search results for Cyprus telemarketing.

Sale of alcoholic beverages through telemarketing must not be directed towards minors, must not depict minors consuming such beverages, must not encourage excessive consumption, and must not provide negative impression of abstinence or measured consumption
Transmission of telemarketing messages is prohibited during children's programmes

Automated calling and communications systems without human intervention, fax and electronic mail may be used for direct marketing purposes only where a subscriber who is a natural person has consented to such use in advance

b2b.description: Opt-in consent required for telemarketing calls. Businesses can contact existing customers without prior consent, but new contacts require explicit consent either individually or via public directory registration.

b2c.description: Opt-in consent required for telemarketing calls. Consumers can only be contacted if they have given prior consent (individual or via public directory) or are existing customers of the business.

b2b.notes: Existing customers can be contacted without prior consent. Businesses must demonstrate how contact was obtained and prove entitlement to treat the contact in this way.

extra_unstructured_rules.text: All forms of communication including advertising and solicitation to visit websites intended to directly or indirectly promote goods, services or image of a person's business are considered commercial communications. Three specific rules apply: (1) Prior consent required, (2) Identification of sender required, (3) Valid address for opt-out requests required.

Each commercial communication must contain a valid address to which recipient can directly and effectively send request to stop receiving commercial information. For SMS, provide telephone number allowing recipient to opt out (e.g., by sending 'stop' or blank message).

extra_unstructured_rules.text: If endorsements or testimonials are used in advertising, they must not be misleading. General rules prohibiting misleading advertising apply. If seller provides access to consumer review, information on whether and how seller ensures published review comes from actual consumer who used/purchased product is essential. Failure to provide this information is misleading omission.

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Czech Telecommunication Office supervises compliance with telemarketing obligations. b2b.description: Telemarketing to businesses may be permitted with presumed consent if it relates to both advertising and the telephone communication channel. However, explicit consent is generally required for most marketing communications.
b2b.type: opt-in with presumed consent exception for B2B

b2c.description: Telemarketing to consumers is strictly prohibited without express prior consent. This is a comprehensive opt-in regime under UWG §7 and GDPR Article 6.

b2b.notes: Presumed consent may be sufficient for B2B if it covers both the advertising content and the telephone channel. However, this is subject to interpretation and companies should document consent carefully.

b2c.notes: Express prior consent is mandatory for all telemarketing calls to consumers. No existing relationship or soft opt-in exemptions apply.

b2b.notes: No explicit exemption found in search results for existing B2B customers.

b2c.notes: No exemption for existing customers in B2C context. Express consent is always required.

retention.max_duration: 5 years from consent date and from each use
retention.notes: Under §7a UWG (Fair Consumer Contracts Act, effective October 2021), companies must document and retain proof of consent for 5 years. Records must be producible to regulators on request.

ai_disclosure.note:
No explicit AI disclosure requirements found in search results for Germany. General transparency principles under GDPR may apply.
Quote requests: It is not possible to reliably determine, using only internal knowledge and without consulting current official German or EU legal sources, whether there are specific, up‑to‑date AI disclosure requirements for telemarketing calls in Germany when the purpose is a quote request (including any distinctions between existing customers and cold calls). No statement can therefore be made on whether AI disclosure is required, not required, or subject to specific exceptions in this context.

caller_id_requirements.note: Under TTDSG §15(2) (effective December 2021), telemarketers must transmit a valid, non-blocked phone number as Caller ID. Withheld ('anonymous') numbers are illegal for marketing calls. Manipulated or unassigned numbers are prohibited. Only officially assigned numbers may be used.

frequency_limits.note: No explicit frequency limits found in search results. However, aggressive repeated calls at close intervals are treated as serious harassment and violations.

legal_restrictions.description: Express prior consent required for all telemarketing calls to consumers
Companies must fully document and retain proof of consent for 5 years
Valid, non-blocked phone number must be transmitted as Caller ID
Manipulated or unassigned numbers are prohibited
Concealing the actual reason for the call or misrepresenting caller identity is prohibited

special_requirements: Companies must be prepared to produce consent records to regulators (Bundesnetzagentur) on request
Omnibus consents (blanket consents) are subject to strict scrutiny and may be invalidated
Aggressive telephone manner, pressure tactics, and repeated calls at close intervals constitute serious violations
Concealing the actual purpose of the call (e.g., pretending to be from the energy supplier or a price comparison site) is a serious violation

rules.caller_id: Valid, non-blocked phone number must be transmitted. Withheld, manipulated, or unassigned numbers are prohibited. Only officially assigned numbers may be used.
rules.exceptions: No exceptions to Caller ID requirements for marketing calls.

max_fine.notes: Maximum fine of €300,000 per incident for illegal telemarketing calls or Caller ID violations. Additional fines up to €50,000 for failure to document or retain consent. In 2023, Bundesnetzagentur imposed €1.435 million in total fines; individual companies were fined €285,000 each for aggressive campaigns.

sources.recent_changes: Danish AI Law introduced 26 February 2025, effective 2 August 2025. EmpCo Directive implemented through amendments to Danish Marketing Act, Consumer Complaints Act, and Consumer Contracts Act; amendments to Consumer Complaints Act entered into force 1 July 2025; full implementation 27 September 2026.

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Denmark implements the Empowering Consumers Directive through amendments to three Danish Acts: the Danish Marketing Act (DMA), the Danish Act on Consumer Complaints, and the Danish Act on Consumer Contracts. The Danish Marketing Act applies to both B2C and B2B relationships and implements the Directive on Misleading and Comparative Advertising between traders.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Complex multi-act implementation with phased entry into force; not easily reducible to single compliance field
extra_unstructured_rules.source: Bird & Bird - EmpCo Directive Tracker for Denmark

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Denmark's AI Law (effective 2 August 2025) requires marketers to audit AI tools for transparency, fairness, and data protection standards; update privacy policies to reflect new consent and disclosure requirements; educate teams on ethical AI practices and legal obligations; ensure cross-functional alignment on compliance.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Operational compliance requirements spanning multiple regulatory areas; not specific to telemarketing calls alone
extra_unstructured_rules.source: Network Scientific Sales - What Marketers Need to Know About Denmark's New AI Law

extra_unstructured_rules.text: AI systems must comply with GDPR and Danish data protection laws, requiring explicit user consent for data use and clear opt-out mechanisms for profiling. Consent management platforms and privacy-first marketing strategies are essential.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: General data protection principle applicable across all marketing channels; not specific to telemarketing
extra_unstructured_rules.source: Network Scientific Sales - What Marketers Need to Know About Denmark's New AI Law

extra_unstructured_rules.text: The Telecommunications Act establishes a comprehensive legal framework regulating the telecommunications sector in Dominica. Any entity seeking to provide telecommunications services must apply for a licence that specifies the type of service, areas of operation, spectrum allocation, infrastructure responsibilities, and required technical compatibility. Operators must demonstrate financial capability, technical competence, and readiness to meet quality benchmarks.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Licensing requirements are foundational to telecom operations but do not directly regulate telemarketing call practices; they establish operator eligibility and operational framework

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Operators must deliver accurate billing, transparent service terms, and accessible complaint procedures. They must meet quality obligations related to call clarity, coverage availability, data throughput, network uptime, and service restoration after failures. Operators must prioritize network restoration after natural hazards and coordinate with emergency-management services.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: These are general service quality obligations rather than specific telemarketing call restrictions; they establish baseline consumer protections applicable to all telecommunications services

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Email marketing in Dominica is governed by Privacy and Electronic Communications Regulations (PECR), which require businesses to obtain consent from individuals before sending marketing communications. Businesses must have explicit permission from the recipient and the recipient must be fully informed about what they are signing up for.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: While PECR applies to electronic communications, specific application to voice telemarketing calls is not explicitly detailed in available sources; this represents the privacy framework applicable to Dominica
extra_unstructured_rules.source: Privacy and Electronic Communications Regulations (PECR), Dominica

b2b.description: B2B telemarketing in Estonia is governed by the Electronic Communications Act and general GDPR principles. Cold calling is allowed for B2B contacts unless they have opted out or the number is marked as not accepting marketing calls. Consent requirements are less stringent than B2C but transparency and opt-out mechanisms must be respected.

b2c.description: B2C telemarketing in Estonia is subject to GDPR and the Electronic Communications Act. Prior consent is generally required for electronic marketing to consumers, with limited exceptions for existing customer relationships. The regime emphasizes data protection and consumer privacy.

b2b.notes: B2B cold calling is permitted in Estonia without prior relationship, provided the contact has not opted out and the number is not marked for exclusion from marketing.

b2c.notes: B2C telemarketing requires prior explicit consent under GDPR. Existing customer exemptions may apply in limited circumstances but are not explicitly detailed in available sources.

b2b.notes: No explicit exemption for existing B2B customers found in available sources. General GDPR principles may apply but specific conditions are not detailed.

b2c.notes: No explicit exemption for existing B2C customers found in available sources. GDPR soft opt-in provisions may theoretically apply but are not specifically codified for Estonia.

retention.notes: No explicit recording requirements or restrictions found in available sources for telemarketing calls.

ai_disclosure.note:
No specific AI disclosure requirements found in available sources for Estonia telemarketing. General GDPR transparency principles may apply.
Quote requests: Unable to determine the current, specific Estonian rules on AI disclosure in telemarketing quote-request calls using only official government or regulatory sources because external legal and government resources cannot be accessed in this environment. No conclusion can be given on whether disclosure is required, whether there are exceptions for quote requests, or whether rules differ for existing customers versus cold calls.

ai_disclosure.note:
No specific AI disclosure requirements found for telemarketing calls
Quote requests: It is not possible to confirm current, specific Ethiopian rules on AI disclosure for telemarketing quote requests using only pre‑existing knowledge. Public analyses of Ethiopia’s emerging AI and data protection framework indicate that, as of 2025, Ethiopia has adopted a National AI Policy and a Personal Data Protection Proclamation but has not yet enacted a dedicated, detailed AI-use or telemarketing-specific disclosure regime comparable to some other jurisdictions. [2][3] These sources, however, are secondary legal and policy commentaries and not official government or regulatory texts, so they cannot be relied on to answer with certainty whether AI disclosure is required or not required specifically for quote-request telemarketing calls, nor whether there are distinctions between existing customers and cold calls. [2][3] Because direct consultation of current Ethiopian government portals, official gazettes, or regulatory authority sites is not available in this context, the existence or absence of narrowly tailored AI disclosure rules for telemarketing quote requests cannot be verified, and no clear exceptions can be documented.

extra_unstructured_rules.text: The Personal Data Protection Proclamation outlines four mechanisms for lawful data transfers: (1) data controller/processor proves destination jurisdiction ensures adequate protection; (2) standard contractual clauses; (3) binding corporate rules; (4) explicit consent. Telecommunications providers must process consumer personal data exclusively on servers or data centres located in Ethiopia (as per ECA consumer rights directive from August 2021).

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Remote services (services provided electronically by seller outside Ethiopia to recipient in Ethiopia) are subject to 15% VAT. Taxable electronic services include: electronic games and betting, internet-based bidding, electronic books and digital content, mobile apps, e-books, movies, subscription media services. Recipient location determined by: billing address in Ethiopia, bank account in Ethiopia, fixed landline in Ethiopia, mobile country code (Ethiopia), IP address/geolocation in Ethiopia, or other commercially relevant information.

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Electronic distribution platforms are liable for remote services they facilitate if they: (1) authorize the charge for supply to recipient; (2) make or authorize delivery of supply; (3) directly or indirectly set terms/conditions under which supply is made.

b2b.description: Permission-based regime with opt-in consent required for automated calls and marketing calls to TPS-registered numbers. Live calls to non-TPS registered business numbers allowed without prior consent unless objection received.

b2c.description: Strict opt-in consent required for all marketing calls. Automated calls require explicit prior consent. Live calls to TPS-registered consumer numbers prohibited without specific consent.

b2b.notes: Live calls to business numbers not on CTPS can be made without prior consent unless the business has objected. However, for automated calls, prior specific consent is always required.

b2c.notes: Explicit opt-in consent required for all marketing calls to consumers. Consent must be freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous (e.g., ticked box or signed form).

b2b.notes: No exemption for existing customers. If a business number is on CTPS, marketing calls are prohibited even to existing customers unless they have specifically opted in.

b2c.notes: No exemption for existing customers. If a consumer number is on TPS, marketing calls are prohibited even to existing customers unless they have specifically opted in.

b2b.description: Georgia's telemarketing law (Title 46, OCGA) prohibits telephone solicitations to residential, mobile, or wireless subscribers who have registered their objection with the state commission. The law applies to both B2B and B2C communications made on behalf of any person or entity.

b2c.description: Georgia's telemarketing law (Title 46, OCGA) prohibits telephone solicitations to residential, mobile, or wireless subscribers who have registered their objection with the state commission. The law applies to both B2B and B2C communications made on behalf of any person or entity.

b2b.notes: No explicit relationship requirements found in Georgia telemarketing law for B2B communications.

b2c.notes: Georgia law does not explicitly require prior existing relationship for telemarketing calls. The primary requirement is compliance with Do-Not-Call registry and caller identification rules.

b2b.notes: No explicit existing customer exemption found in Georgia telemarketing law for B2B.

b2c.notes: No explicit existing customer exemption found in Georgia telemarketing law for B2C. However, there is a defense if a telephone number was provided in error by another subscriber and the defendant did not know or have reason to know of the error.

retention.notes: No specific recording requirements found in Georgia telemarketing law. Federal TCPA rules may apply for certain types of calls.

ai_disclosure.note:
No explicit AI disclosure requirement found in Georgia state telemarketing law. However, federal FCC rules (effective January 27, 2025) require prior express written consent for calls using artificial intelligence, and the FCC clarified in 2024 that AI-generated voices count as 'artificial' under TCPA.
Quote requests: It is not possible to perform the requested up-to-date internet search of official Georgia government or regulatory sites in this environment, so no specific, current rules on AI disclosure for telemarketing quote requests (including distinctions between existing customers and cold calls) can be confirmed. Because the relevant primary legal texts and official guidance cannot be accessed or verified here, no definitive statement can be made about whether AI disclosure is required or not required in Georgia (GE) for this specific use case.

caller_id_requirements.note: Georgia law requires that the caller must state their identity and the location of the business they are calling on behalf of. Blocking or circumventing caller ID is prohibited.

frequency_limits.note: No specific frequency limits found in Georgia telemarketing law.

legal_restrictions.description: No person or entity shall make or cause to be made on behalf of any person or entity any telephone solicitation to the telephone line of any residential, mobile, or wireless subscriber in Georgia who has given notice to the commission of their objection to receiving telephone solicitations.
legal_restrictions.applies_to: All telemarketing calls to residential, mobile, or wireless subscribers
legal_restrictions.enforcement_level: Strict liability (no 'knowing' requirement as of July 1, 2024)

legal_restrictions.description: As of July 1, 2024 (SB 73), liability extends to any person or entity on whose behalf telephone solicitations are made in violation of the law. This includes advertisers and businesses that benefit from the calls, even if they contracted with third-party vendors.
legal_restrictions.value: Businesses can be held liable for violations by their telemarketing vendors
legal_restrictions.applies_to: All parties benefiting from telemarketing calls

legal_restrictions.description: As of July 1, 2024 (SB 73), ignorance of the law is no longer a valid defense. Defendants are liable even if unaware that the telemarketing conduct violated the law.
As of July 1, 2024 (SB 73), plaintiffs can bring claims as part of a class action and recover reasonable attorneys' fees. Damages cap for class actions has been removed.
legal_restrictions.applies_to: Private right of action for telemarketing violations
legal_restrictions.enforcement_level: High risk due to unlimited damages

special_requirements: Maintain detailed call records including dates, times, durations, and outcomes for up to five years (federal TSR requirement as of May 2024)
Obtain prior express written consent for calls using automated telephone dialing systems or artificial/prerecorded voices (federal TCPA requirement)
Honor consumer revocation requests within 10 business days using any reasonable method such as 'stop' or 'unsubscribe' (federal TCPA requirement effective January 27, 2025)
Ensure consent is obtained on a one-to-one basis for each individual telemarketer (federal FCC requirement effective January 27, 2025)

rules.caller_id: Caller must state their identity and the location of the business they are calling on behalf of. Blocking or circumventing caller ID is prohibited.
rules.exceptions: If a telephone number was provided in error by another subscriber and the defendant did not know or have reason to know of the error, the defendant is not liable.

max_fine.notes: Enforcement actions brought by the Georgia Attorney General can have a penalty of $1,000 per violation. Private plaintiffs can pursue class actions with unlimited damages as of July 1, 2024.

sources.recent_changes: SB 73 (effective July 1, 2024) made significant amendments: (1) removed the 'knowing' requirement for violations; (2) extended vicarious liability to parties benefiting from telemarketing calls made on their behalf; (3) removed damages cap for class actions; (4) allowed class action lawsuits with recovery of reasonable attorneys' fees; (5) added defense for numbers provided in error by another subscriber.

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Georgia's telemarketing law works in conjunction with the federal Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA). Text messages sent to Georgia residents are covered under federal TCPA rules even though they are not explicitly mentioned in Georgia's state law definition of telephone solicitation. Organizations should apply the same policies and procedures to text messages as phone calls.

legal_restrictions.description: All telemarketing must be conducted through registered entities only. Unregistered telemarketers (UTMs) are prohibited.
Telemarketers must scrub calling lists daily against the National Customer Preference Register (NCPR/DND registry) and honor consumer opt-out requests.
If promotional content is mixed with other types of commercial communication, the entire message/call is treated as promotional and requires explicit consent.
Telecom operators must provide mandatory opt-out option in promotional messages, allowing customers to easily modify preferences.

special_requirements: Physical verification, biometric authentication, and unique mobile number linking required during telemarketer registration

rules.caller_id: Mandatory use of 140 series for promotional calls and 160 series for transactional/service calls. Spoofing and anonymous calls prohibited.
rules.exceptions: Government messages and government voice calls are exempt from certain restrictions. Transactional and service communications with inferred consent are permitted without explicit opt-in.

max_fine.notes: Penalties up to ₹10 lakh (1,000,000 INR) for violations. Graded penalties: ₹2L for first violation, ₹5L for second, ₹10L for subsequent violations. Financial disincentives also apply to access providers for misreporting UCC counts.

sources.recent_changes: Iran's parliament passed the Combating the Spread of Untrue News Content bill on July 27, 2025 (205 in favor, 49 against), significantly expanding restrictions on online communications and criminalizing 'untrue news content.' Communications restrictions through certain platforms became effective March 15, 2025.

extra_unstructured_rules.text: The 2025 law redefines the offense of spreading false information online from 'spreading lies' (previously punishable by up to 2 years imprisonment) to the broader category of 'untrue news content,' which criminalizes partial truths, inaccuracies, or omissions. This significantly expands what constitutes a criminal offense in telemarketing communications.

b2b.description: B2B telemarketing calls are subject to misrepresentation prohibitions under ePrivacy regulations. Prior consent requirements are less stringent than B2C, but false or misleading statements are prohibited.

b2c.description: B2C telemarketing requires affirmative consent (opt-in) for electronic direct marketing. Marketing calls to mobile phones are prohibited unless the subscriber has consented to receipt of such calls.

b2b.notes: B2B calls are subject to misrepresentation prohibitions but not to the same consent requirements as B2C. However, specific relationship requirements are not detailed in available sources.

b2c.notes: For B2C, affirmative consent is required. A soft opt-in exemption applies if the sale of the product or service occurred not more than twelve months prior to the sending of the electronic marketing communication, or contact details were used for marketing in that twelve-month period. Each marketing message must provide the right to object to further messages.

b2b.notes: No explicit exemption for existing B2B customers found in available sources.

legal_restrictions.description: Call centers and third-party companies conducting telemarketing activities must be registered in the Registro degli Operatori di Comunicazione (ROC). Registration requires communication of all numerations used, including toll-free numbers.

Falsification of caller ID numbers is prohibited. International calls with falsified Italian fixed numbers have been blocked since August 19, 2025. International calls with falsified Italian mobile numbers have been blocked since November 19, 2025.
Telemarketing calls require prior opt-in consent from recipients. Legitimate commercial calls are only permitted from companies registered in ROC.

special_requirements: Operators must apply automated real-time controls to block international calls with falsified Italian numbers
For mobile numbers, operators must consult a national database to verify if the number is actually active in Italy or in roaming
Operators must publish lists of mobile operators managing roaming users on AGCOM's institutional website
Simplified blocking procedures apply for calls from mobile operators not managing users in roaming

rules.caller_id: Spoofing is prohibited. Caller ID must display authentic numbers. International calls with falsified Italian numbers (fixed since Aug 19, 2025; mobile since Nov 19, 2025) are automatically blocked by operators.
rules.exceptions: Legitimate telemarketing calls from ROC-registered operators with authentic Italian numbers may continue. Calls originating from Italy with authentic Italian numbers are not blocked by the anti-spoofing filter.

max_fine.notes: Fines up to €1,000,000 for serious violations including spoofing and fraudulent telemarketing. Fines up to €50,000 for unauthorized telemarketing activities without ROC registration. Activity blocking may also be imposed.

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Jamaica-based call centers serving US customers must comply with proposed Keep Call Centers in America Act 2025. Key requirements: (1) Disclose agent location (Jamaica) at start of call; (2) Disclose whether caller is speaking to AI or human; (3) Allow US customers to request US-based representative; (4) US companies must provide 120 days notice before moving operations to Jamaica; (5) Companies relocating jobs overseas face listing on public 'offshoring list' for up to 5 years with penalties including ineligibility for federal grants, loans, and contracts.

b2b.description: B2B telemarketing is regulated under the Telecommunications Business Act and Network Act. Prior consent is generally required for marketing calls, with specific registration requirements for bulk messaging.

b2c.description: B2C telemarketing requires prior opt-in consent under the Personal Information Protection Act (PIPA) and Network Act. Telemarketers must register with authorities and comply with Do-Not-Call registry requirements.

b2b.notes: Prior consent required for marketing calls and bulk SMS/MMS messages sent via web or PC applications.

b2c.notes: Prior opt-in consent mandatory under PIPA and Network Act. Personal data must be used only for agreed purposes (data minimization and purpose limitation).

recording.basis: legal obligation for financial products; quality and training purposes for general calls
exceptions: One-party consent basis: recording is lawful if either caller or callee consents
Financial product calls (insurance, loans) must be recorded and retained as evidence of compliance

retention.notes: Financial product calls must retain recordings as compliance evidence; general retention period not specified in search results.

ai_disclosure.note:
No explicit AI disclosure requirements found in search results for South Korea telemarketing regulations.
Quote requests: South Korea's AI Framework Act, effective January 2026, requires AI business operators to notify users when a product or service is operated by AI, including for telemarketing calls and quote requests. There are no explicit exceptions for quote requests or for existing customers versus cold calling. All AI-generated communications must be clearly disclosed to users.

quiet_hours.note: South Korean law does not specify exact telemarketing calling hours in statutes, but authorities expect reasonable calling times. Industry best practices suggest avoiding early morning or late-night calls. Excessively frequent calls or calls at inappropriate times could be deemed violations of consumer rights.

caller_id_requirements.note: Telemarketers must not spoof or conceal caller identification. The number shown must be a valid callback number or one registered to the calling entity. Telecom regulations (KCC and MSIT) were strengthened in 2015 to combat caller ID spoofing.

frequency_limits.note: No specific frequency limits found in search results. General consumer protection covers harassment through repeatedly calling at odd hours.

legal_restrictions.description: At the start of a call, telemarketers must clearly inform the consumer that this is a sales/solicitation call and provide their identity and purpose (name or company name and product/service being promoted).
Telemarketers must disclose the source of the consumer's contact information during a sales call.
Companies (domestic or foreign) engaged in telephone solicitation sales to consumers must register or file a report before operating.
Businesses sending bulk SMS/MMS from websites or PC applications must register with the Ministry of Science and ICT (MSIT).
Direct sellers cannot sell drugs, toxic chemicals, or insurance via telemarketing.

special_requirements: Telemarketers must comply with PIPA (Personal Information Protection Act) data minimization and purpose limitation requirements.
Financial product telemarketing (insurance, loans) subject to additional Financial Supervisory Service (FSS) requirements including script approval, mandatory disclosures, and cooling-off periods.
Telemarketing businesses must register with KFTC (Korea Fair Trade Commission) and comply with the Door-to-Door Sales, Telemarketing, and Multilevel Marketing Act.
Consumers can opt-out via the official DNC registry (donotcall.go.kr) managed by KFTC/KCA.
Violations can be reported through the DNC portal for KFTC follow-up.

rules.caller_id: Telemarketers must display a valid callback number or one registered to the calling entity. Spoofing and concealment of caller ID are prohibited.
rules.exceptions: No exceptions to caller ID requirements found in search results.

max_fine.notes: Specific fine amounts not detailed in search results. Enforcement handled by KCC, MSIT, KFTC, and FSS depending on violation type.

legal_restrictions.description: False or deceptive claims about product quality, origin, pricing, or benefits are prohibited. Advertisers must provide evidence for claims if requested by authorities.
Businesses must display prices clearly in all advertisements. Prices cannot be changed after advertising.
Influencers and promoters must clearly indicate paid or sponsored promotions to avoid misleading consumers.
Publishing false testimonials or manipulated ratings is considered misleading advertising and is prohibited.
If a product has potential health or safety concerns, businesses must clearly warn consumers.
Before-and-after images and visual claims must be scientifically verified.

special_requirements: Businesses must provide digital or physical invoices for online purchases
Consumers have the right to cancel online purchases within 10 days (except custom orders or used products)
Businesses cannot unilaterally change price or delivery conditions after accepting payment
All key terms must be visible in ads or clearly linked terms page; hidden terms and conditions are prohibited
Discounts and special offers must have clear expiration dates; if unspecified, offer is valid for one month
Businesses must maintain digital records of electronic contracts ensuring transparency and accessibility

max_fine.notes: Fines for misleading online advertising range from 10 million to 50 million Lebanese pounds, with possible imprisonment.

The Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA) grants data subjects specific rights including the right to access, rectify, erase and object to the processing of their personal data. Data controllers and processors must comply with principles of lawfulness, fairness, transparency, purpose limitation, data minimisation and accountability.
legal_restrictions.applies_to: All entities collecting, analysing or storing personal data of Sri Lankan residents

legal_restrictions.description: Cross-border transfers of personal data are permitted only if the recipient country or foreign entity ensures an adequate level of data protection, or where appropriate safeguards are in place (such as standard contractual clauses or binding corporate rules).

special_requirements: Foreign companies collecting, analysing or storing personal data of Sri Lankan residents via websites, apps or other digital platforms are subject to the same obligations as local data controllers and processors under the PDPA.
The Personal Data Protection Authority is empowered to collaborate with international regulatory bodies and to issue adequacy decisions or approve cross-border transfer mechanisms.
Data subjects have the right to object to the processing of their personal data.

sources.recent_changes: Luxembourg adopted law of 4 April 2025 implementing Digital Services Act (DSA); Draft Bill n° 8625 submitted 30 September 2025 modernizing Media Law and implementing European Media Freedom Act. New Electronic Communications Code (Loi du 30 mai 2024) maintains prior consent requirement for unsolicited marketing calls (Article 108).

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Luxembourg adopted law of 4 April 2025 implementing Regulation (EU) 2022/2065. Very large online platforms (VLOPs) and very large online search engines (VLOSEs) with over 45 million EU users monthly must implement mechanisms to detect and remove illegal content, ensure transparency in algorithmic systems and advertising, and provide enhanced user protections. Applies extraterritorially to any provider offering services to users in EU.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Applies to digital platforms and online services, not traditional telemarketing, but relevant for AI-based or digital telemarketing services
extra_unstructured_rules.source: Goodwin Law - Luxembourg Takes Legislative Step to Implement the Digital Services Act (April 2025)

extra_unstructured_rules.topic: Media Law Modernization and Political Advertising
extra_unstructured_rules.text: Draft Bill n° 8625 (submitted 30 September 2025) modernizes Luxembourg media law and implements EU Regulation 2024/900 on political advertising (effective 10 October 2025). Entities providing political advertising services disseminated in or targeting EU must be established in EU and controlled by EU citizen or third-country national permanently residing in Union with voting rights. Influencers and content creators who monetize audience are now considered media service providers subject to same obligations as traditional broadcasters.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Relevant for AI-based marketing and influencer outreach; introduces new compliance requirements for political advertising and content creators
extra_unstructured_rules.source: DLA Piper - Luxembourg modernises Media Law (22 October 2025); Nauta Dutilh - Luxembourg unveils major reform of the media sector rules

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Prohibition of targeted advertising to minors. Commercial profiling or targeted advertising using minors' personal data is expressly prohibited. Media services must adopt age classification systems, parental controls, and content-locking mechanisms. Commercial content must not promote behavior harmful to health, safety, or environment, or exploit minors.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Specific restriction on marketing practices targeting minors; applies to both traditional and digital marketing
extra_unstructured_rules.source: DLA Piper - Luxembourg modernises Media Law; Nauta Dutilh - Luxembourg unveils major reform of the media sector rules

extra_unstructured_rules.topic: Right to Object to Direct Marketing
extra_unstructured_rules.text: Data subjects have an unconditional right to object to and prevent any form of direct marketing, including electronic direct marketing. This right is absolute and must be respected by all service providers.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Fundamental consumer right that supersedes other exemptions; critical for compliance
extra_unstructured_rules.source: DLA Piper Data Protection Laws in Luxembourg

legal_restrictions.description: The new Electronic Communications Act (ECA) effective 1 June 2026 mandates that operators provide contracts in clearer, more detailed and accessible format, explicitly listing all essential service elements, quality parameters and user rights.

The ECA requires operators to offer both 12- and 24-month contract options, introduces stricter rules on automatic renewals, and ensures users can terminate contracts without penalty in cases of non-fulfilment or unfavourable changes.
Number portability is streamlined with a one-day transfer process, no end-user charges, and automatic contract termination upon switching.

Amendments to the Consumer Protection Law effective 18 April 2025 require retailers to publish product prices on their websites on a daily basis. Traders of all sizes have this obligation except micro traders. Retailers with multiple outlets must display prices for each location individually.

special_requirements: The new Electronic Communications Act (ECA) entered into force on the eighth day following its publication in the Official Gazette of the Republic of North Macedonia and will start to apply from 1 June 2026.
Operators must align their operations in accordance with the ECA and provide all necessary technical means and organisational measures within 18 months of its entry into force.
The ECA mandates that the Agency for Electronic Communications (AEC) provide an independent comparison tool for consumers to access transparent, comparable information on prices and service quality.
The ECA expands transparency obligations requiring operators to publish up-to-date, comparable information on prices and service quality.

max_fine.notes: No specific fine amounts for telemarketing violations found in available sources for North Macedonia.

legal_restrictions.description: Article 32B of Commercial Code prohibits traders from engaging in any form of misleading advertising. Unfair commercial practices that mislead, manipulate, or significantly impair consumer freedom of choice are prohibited.
Broadcasting Act prohibits advertising not immediately recognisable as such (surreptitious or secretive audiovisual commercial communication) as it might mislead the public.
Broadcasting Act prohibits subliminal advertising techniques.

Under Consumer Affairs Act, Commercial Code, and Unfair Commercial Practices Directive (2005/29/EC), any design feature in advertising or online platforms that misleads, manipulates, or significantly impairs consumer freedom of choice is prohibited. Digital Services Act (DSA) restricts use of dark patterns on online platforms.

Article 16K of Broadcasting Act restricts audiovisual commercial communications that would cause physical, mental or moral detriment to minors. Broadcasting Code for Protection of Minors (S.L. 350.05) elaborates restrictions to protect minors from advertising effects.

special_requirements: Consent must be obtained for processing personal data for direct marketing purposes under Data Protection Act (Chapter 586)
Sponsorship agreements and branded content must be clearly disclosed to viewers under Broadcasting Act
Marketing to minors restricted under Broadcasting Code and Data Protection Act
Sweepstakes, contests, and promotional games fall under Malta Gaming Authority supervision under Gaming Act
Behavioural and targeted advertising must comply with GDPR consent requirements
ePrivacy Directive requirements apply to electronic direct marketing

max_fine.notes: Consumer violations under Consumer Affairs Act punishable by fines up to EUR 47,000. Broadcasting Act violations punishable by fines up to EUR 11,646, six-month prison term, or both.

b2b.description: Mexico applies a consent-based framework for telemarketing under the Federal Consumer Protection Law (LFPC) and the new Federal Law on Telecommunications and Broadcasting (LMTR, effective July 17, 2025). B2B communications are subject to the same DNC registry (REPEP) and opt-out requirements as B2C, with no explicit exemption for business-to-business relationships.

b2c.description: Opt-out regime with mandatory DNC registry (REPEP) compliance. Consumers must explicitly opt out of telemarketing. The new LMTR (July 2025) reinforces consumer protection and establishes PROFECO as the enforcement authority for user rights and telemarketing regulations.

b2b.notes: No explicit B2B exemption found in Mexican law. B2B contacts are subject to the same REPEP DNC registry requirements as B2C.

b2c.notes: Mexico operates on an opt-out model. Consumers must register with REPEP to block calls; absence from registry does not imply consent.

b2b.notes: No explicit existing customer exemption identified in Mexican telemarketing law.

b2c.notes: No explicit existing customer exemption identified in Mexican telemarketing law. All consumers, including existing customers, are protected by REPEP.

recording.basis: legal obligation for surveillance and compliance
exceptions: Real-time geolocation and metadata retention are maintained as surveillance-related obligations under the new LMTR (2025)

retention.notes: The new LMTR maintains surveillance-related obligations including real-time geolocation and metadata retention, but specific retention periods are not detailed in available sources.

ai_disclosure.note:
No explicit AI disclosure requirements found in Mexican telemarketing or telecommunications law as of July 2025.
Quote requests: It is not possible to reliably determine the current, specific Mexican rules on AI disclosure in telemarketing quote-request calls using only internal knowledge. A review of the applicable framework would require direct consultation of up‑to‑date official government and regulatory sources (such as federal laws, regulations, and consumer‑protection or data‑protection authority publications). Because those sources cannot be checked here, no clear conclusion can be drawn on whether AI disclosure is required, not required, or treated differently for existing customers versus cold calls.

caller_id_requirements.note: No explicit caller ID requirements or spoofing prohibitions found in available Mexican telemarketing regulations.

frequency_limits.note: No specific frequency limits (calls per day/week/month) identified in Mexican telemarketing law.

legal_restrictions.description: Telemarketers must not contact consumers registered in REPEP. Prohibited from calling or sending marketing messages to consumers who have opted out or expressly indicated they do not wish to receive advertising.
legal_restrictions.value: 30 calendar days to cease calls after registration

legal_restrictions.description: The new LMTR (2025) prohibits advertising via broadcasting and telecommunication channels from foreign governments, except for tourism, cultural, or sporting purposes.
All mobile lines must be linked to the national identity number (CURP) and include biometric data. Raises privacy, cybersecurity, and compliance challenges under the Federal Data Protection Law.
The new LMTR reaffirms network neutrality as a constitutional principle, guaranteeing non-discriminatory open interconnection across networks.

special_requirements: Compliance with REPEP (DNC registry) is mandatory; telemarketers have 30 calendar days to cease calls after consumer registration.
PROFECO (Federal Consumer Protection Agency) enforces user rights and telemarketing regulations under the new LMTR.
The new LMTR (effective July 17, 2025) introduces the Digital Transformation and Telecommunications Agency (ATDT) and the Telecommunications Regulatory Commission (CRT) as primary regulators.
Digital platforms are now explicitly regulated under the new LMTR with possibility of temporary suspension under certain circumstances.
Compliance with Federal Data Protection Law required for handling personal data, including CURP and biometric information.

max_fine.notes: Specific fine amounts for telemarketing violations not detailed in available sources. PROFECO can impose penalties, suspensions of operations (up to 90 days), and additional sanctions for serious or repeat violations.

sources.recent_changes: New Federal Law on Telecommunications and Broadcasting (LMTR) effective July 17, 2025, replacing the 2014 law. Dissolves IFT, establishes ATDT and CRT as new regulatory bodies. Introduces mandatory CURP and biometric registration for mobile lines, reinforces network neutrality, and expands digital platform regulation.

extra_unstructured_rules.text: The Instituto Federal de Telecomunicaciones (IFT) is dissolved. The Agencia de Transformación Digital y Telecomunicaciones (ATDT) becomes the policy-making authority. The Comisión Reguladora de Telecomunicaciones (CRT), under ATDT, regulates spectrum, licensing, infrastructure, and broadcasting, with power to approve tariffs and revoke concessions.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Institutional changes affect regulatory oversight but do not directly establish telemarketing rules; relevant for understanding enforcement authority.

extra_unstructured_rules.text: The IFT remains operational on a transitional basis until the CRT Plenary is fully established. Ongoing applications are not canceled but transferred to the CRT. Existing certificates remain valid until expiration. The IFT Seal labeling requirement, originally scheduled for July 1, 2025, has been postponed to July 1, 2027.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Transitional provisions affect implementation timeline but do not establish substantive telemarketing compliance rules.
extra_unstructured_rules.source: IB Lenhardt - Mexico Introduces New Telecom Law (July 16, 2025)

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Consumers can register their phone numbers (mobile or landline) with REPEP by calling a designated number or via PROFECO's website to opt out of telemarketing calls for goods, products, or services. Once registered, telemarketers have 30 calendar days to cease advertising calls. Companies are prohibited from calling or sending marketing messages to consumers who have registered or expressly indicated they do not wish to receive advertising.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Detailed operational procedure for DNC compliance; core enforcement mechanism for telemarketing regulation.
extra_unstructured_rules.source: TALK-Q - Outbound Call and Data Privacy Regulations in Mexico

extra_unstructured_rules.text: The Public Registry of Users (REUS) is a tool that allows blocking promotional calls from banks, insurers, retirement funds, and telephone companies in Mexico. REUS and REPEP are two mechanisms provided by the Federal Government to manage promotional calls.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Complementary DNC mechanism for specific sectors; provides additional consumer protection option.
extra_unstructured_rules.source: News O-Abroad - New Registration to Prevent Telemarketing Calls in Mexico

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Digital platforms are now explicitly regulated under the new LMTR with the possibility of temporary suspension under certain circumstances. Foreign government propaganda is prohibited on radio, television, and digital platforms, except for cultural or tourism purposes.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Affects digital telemarketing and AI-driven outreach; establishes new regulatory framework for digital communications.

b2b.description: Opt-in consent required for unsolicited commercial electronic messages (UCEM). Express consent must be obtained prior to sending commercial messages. Implied consent allowed only from existing business relationships within specific timeframes.

b2c.description: Opt-in consent required for unsolicited commercial electronic messages (UCEM). Express consent must be obtained prior to sending commercial messages. Implied consent allowed only from existing relationships within specific timeframes.

b2b.recent_interaction_window: 24 months from last transaction or 6 months from last inquiry if no transaction occurred
b2b.soft_opt_in_expiry: 24 months from last transaction or 6 months from last inquiry
b2b.notes: Express consent requires clear affirmative act (e.g., checking unchecked box, submitting form). Implied consent can be inferred from existing relationship but message content must be directly related to that relationship. Senders must maintain records of relationship.

b2b.notes: Implied consent does not eliminate opt-out rights. Recipients must still be able to opt out, and opt-out requests must be processed within 5 business days.

ai_disclosure.note:
No explicit AI disclosure requirements found in current Malaysian telemarketing/UCEM regulations. Falls under general transparency and sender identification requirements.
Quote requests: At the moment, there is no direct access to up-to-date official Malaysian government or regulatory sources to verify whether AI disclosure is specifically required or exempted for telemarketing quote requests, nor whether the rules differ between existing customers and cold calls. Because of this lack of verifiable official information in this environment, it is not possible to state clearly whether AI disclosure is required, not required, or subject to specific exceptions for quote-request telemarketing in Malaysia.

caller_id_requirements.note: Clear sender identification mandatory. Message must clearly display sender's name or legally registered business identity and provide functional, responsive, accessible contact details. Contact information must be accurate and functional for at least 30 calendar days. Prefix '[AD]' followed by space must appear at beginning of subject line (or first line of message body if no subject line) to identify message as advertisement.

frequency_limits.note: No explicit frequency limits found in proposed UCEM framework

legal_restrictions.description: Prohibition on sending UCEM without prior consent or existing relationship. Section 233A of Communications and Multimedia Act 1998 prohibits sending, causing to be sent, or authorizing sending of UCEM.

Section 507A of Penal Code criminalizes stalking, including repeated unsolicited calls/messages causing fear or distress. More than one instance of online tracking or attempting to communicate constitutes stalking.
legal_restrictions.value: Up to 3 years jail or fine
legal_restrictions.applies_to: repeated unsolicited communications causing fear or distress

legal_restrictions.description: Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA) prohibits improper processing, buying, and selling of personal data. Acquiring, distributing, making available, or using personal data improperly is prohibited.
legal_restrictions.value: Up to RM1,000,000 fine or up to 3 years jail

legal_restrictions.description: Every UCEM must contain free, clear, functional mechanism for recipients to unsubscribe. Opt-out requests must be processed within 5 business days. Mechanism must remain operational for at least 30 calendar days.
Subject line must accurately reflect message content and not be false, misleading, or deceptive. Advertisement prefix '[AD]' must appear at beginning of subject line or first line of message body.

special_requirements: Sender must provide functional, responsive, and accessible contact details that can be easily used
Contact information must be accurate and functional for at least 30 calendar days
Consent records must be verifiable and maintained by sender
Consent must be voluntary, specific to purpose of receiving CEMs, with transparent disclosure of sender identity, message purpose, and message types
Recipients must have free and accessible way to withdraw consent
Withdrawal requests must be processed within 10 working days
Message must have Malaysian link (sender-based, recipient-based, or infrastructure-based connection)

rules.caller_id: Clear sender identification mandatory with company name or legally registered business identity. Functional contact details required. Advertisement prefix '[AD]' must appear at beginning of subject line or first line of message body.
rules.exceptions: No explicit exceptions to caller ID requirements found in proposed framework

max_fine.notes: Up to RM1,000,000 fine for improper data processing under PDPA. Up to RM500,000 fine or up to 3 years jail for violations of Communications and Multimedia Act Section 233(1)(b). Up to RM50,000 fine or up to 1 year jail for general CMA violations. Up to 3 years jail for stalking under Penal Code Section 507A.
