sources.recent_changes: MCMC issued public consultation paper on 13 August 2025 proposing comprehensive regulatory framework for UCEM. Framework expected to be developed into subsidiary legislation to complement Section 233A of CMA. Public consultation period ended 27 August 2025. Framework addresses nearly 200% surge in spam complaints between 2021-2025.

extra_unstructured_rules.text: UCEM regulations apply to messages with Malaysian link, which exists if: (1) Sender is physically present in Malaysia, Malaysian citizen/permanent resident, or organization formed/incorporated/carrying on business in Malaysia; (2) Message sent to individual/organization physically present in Malaysia or Malaysian citizen/permanent resident/organization in Malaysia; or (3) Message accessed via computer/server/network infrastructure in Malaysia.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Complex jurisdictional rule with multiple alternative conditions
extra_unstructured_rules.source: MCMC Proposed Framework for UCEM, August 2025

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Express consent requires clear, affirmative act from recipient (e.g., checking unchecked box, submitting form). Must be voluntary, specific to purpose of receiving CEMs. Sender identity, message purpose, and message types must be transparently disclosed. Recipients must have free and accessible way to withdraw consent with requests processed within 10 working days. Senders must keep verifiable records of how and when consent was obtained.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Multi-part consent framework with specific procedural requirements
extra_unstructured_rules.source: MCMC Proposed Framework for UCEM, August 2025

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Implied consent can be reasonably inferred from existing or prior relationship such as commercial transaction, membership, or subscription. Message content must be directly related to that relationship. Implied consent subject to time limitations: up to 24 months from last transaction or 6 months from last inquiry if no transaction occurred. Recipients must still be able to opt out. Senders must maintain records of relationship from which consent was derived.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Specific timeframe and relationship-based exemption with conditions
extra_unstructured_rules.source: MCMC Proposed Framework for UCEM, August 2025

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Malaysia currently lacks dedicated legal framework for UCEM. Section 233(1)(b) of CMA allows prosecution if communication intended to annoy, abuse, threaten, or harass. However, CMA does not provide civil sanctions (financial penalties, enforceable undertakings, injunctions). Violations punishable by up to 1 year jail or fine not exceeding RM50,000. PDPA violations carry up to RM1,000,000 fine or 3 years jail. Stalking under Penal Code Section 507A carries up to 3 years jail.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Summary of current enforcement landscape prior to proposed framework implementation
extra_unstructured_rules.source: Communications and Multimedia Act 1998, Personal Data Protection Act, Penal Code Section 507A, Malay Mail 2024

extra_unstructured_rules.text: As of 11 November 2025, MCMC requires local Malaysian address for all Toll-Free RC (Regulatory Compliance) bundles. Existing numbers remain active, but new Toll-Free purchases require updated bundles with local Malaysian address.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Recent regulatory requirement specific to toll-free infrastructure

Quote requests: It is not possible to reliably determine from here whether Mozambique currently requires AI disclosure for telemarketing calls when the purpose is a quote request, or whether there are specific exceptions or distinctions between existing customers and cold calls. Publicly discussed Mozambican digital and data-governance measures mainly address electronic transactions, data protection, cybersecurity, and general electronic marketing rules, but do not clearly set out AI-specific disclosure obligations in telemarketing contexts. Because no AI-specific telemarketing disclosure rules tailored to quote requests could be identified with certainty from official, up-to-date primary sources, the legal status of AI disclosure for such calls remains unclear and should be confirmed directly with competent Mozambican authorities or local counsel.

ai_disclosure.note:
No explicit AI disclosure requirements found in available New Zealand sources. TCPA (US) requires AI disclosure but does not apply to New Zealand.
Quote requests: Current official New Zealand regulations do not specify a requirement for AI disclosure in telemarketing calls for quote requests. The Privacy Amendment Act 2025 introduces new notification requirements for indirect collection of personal information, but does not explicitly address AI disclosure for telemarketing or quote requests. Existing guidance focuses on privacy, consent, and transparency, but does not differentiate between quote requests and other telemarketing activities or between existing customers and cold calls. No official sources confirm an exemption or requirement for AI disclosure in this context.

special_requirements: Sender identification must clearly and accurately identify the individual or organization sending the message

Contact details for business or link to business contact details must be included in every CEM
Transactional messages (order confirmations, shipping notifications, appointment reminders, account security) require only express consent
Promotional messages (sales offers, marketing campaigns, cross-selling) require prior express written consent

b2b.description: Opt-in consent required for all commercial communications via electronic channels, including telemarketing. Article 398 of the Electronic Communications Law (ECL) requires prior explicit consent before sending any commercial communication, even in B2B cases.

b2c.description: Opt-in consent required for all commercial communications via electronic channels. Article 398 of the Electronic Communications Law (ECL) prohibits sending unsolicited commercial information without prior explicit consent.

b2b.notes: Article 398 ECL requires prior explicit consent for all commercial communications in B2B context. No exemption for existing business relationships found in ECL.

b2c.notes: Article 398 ECL requires prior explicit consent for all commercial communications. Consent must be freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous (Article 400 ECL, applying GDPR consent rules).

b2b.notes: No existing customer exemption found in ECL. Opt-in consent is required for all commercial communications regardless of prior business relationship.

b2c.notes: No existing customer exemption found in ECL. Opt-in consent is required for all commercial communications regardless of prior customer relationship.

retention.notes: Article 349 ECL requires providers to record subscriber's consent for direct billing and deliver it to the subscriber on a durable medium. Recording of consent is mandatory for compliance documentation.

ai_disclosure.note:
No explicit AI disclosure requirements found in ECL or related Polish telemarketing regulations. General transparency principles apply under ECL Article 285 (pre-contractual information requirements).
Quote requests: There is currently no specific Polish law or official regulation mandating AI disclosure for telemarketing calls, including quote requests, nor are there explicit exceptions for such cases. The EU AI Act and GDPR require transparency for automated decision-making and high-risk AI systems, but do not specify disclosure requirements for telemarketing quote requests. Poland is in the process of drafting AI-specific legislation, but as of now, no official source confirms mandatory disclosure for this scenario.

caller_id_requirements.note: No specific caller ID requirements found in ECL or Polish telemarketing regulations. General transparency principles apply.

frequency_limits.note: No explicit frequency limits found in ECL or Polish telemarketing regulations.

Prior explicit consent required before sending any commercial communication via electronic channels

Separate consent should be obtained for each communication channel (e.g., distinct checkboxes for email and SMS)

special_requirements: Providers must give consumers clear, free information about the service and a summary of terms before contract conclusion (Article 285-287 ECL)

sources.recent_changes: Electronic Communications Law (ECL) came into force on November 10, 2024, replacing the 2004 Telecommunications Law. ECL expands scope to include providers of electronic communications services (email, instant messaging, group chats, online meeting tools, messaging applications, video conferencing platforms). Introduces stricter opt-in requirements for all commercial communications.

extra_unstructured_rules.text: ECL applies to providers of electronic communications services, not just telecommunications services. This includes email, instant messaging, group chats, messaging applications, video conferencing platforms, and online meeting tools. Providers of interpersonal communication services are not required to register in the Telecommunications Undertakings Register but must comply with ECL obligations.

Digital Services Act implemented July 31, 2025, with ANACOM appointed as competent authority. Phone number spoofing complaints more than doubled in 2025 (70 complaints vs. 30 in 2024).

sources.recent_changes: Major regulatory shift in 2025: PTS prohibited number sub-allocation (June 2025); Consumer Agency proposed complete telemarketing ban (August 2025); Parliament motion filed for investigation into total ban (September 2025)

extra_unstructured_rules.text: The Swedish Consumer Agency has formally recommended a complete ban on telemarketing to the government. Director-General Cecilia Tisell stated the business method is 'problematic in its basic construction' and that 'supervision or stricter rules are not enough.' Civil Minister Erik Slottner indicated openness to the ban but no concrete legislative proposal has been developed yet. Previous similar proposals have been rejected by Parliament.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Proposal status is fluid and not yet law; represents regulatory direction rather than binding requirement

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Six out of ten Swedish consumers avoid answering calls from unknown numbers to evade sales pitches, unintentionally missing important calls from health services and law enforcement. Vulnerable groups (elderly, those with language difficulties, people with disabilities) are disproportionately affected by telemarketing.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Contextual information about regulatory rationale rather than specific compliance rule

extra_unstructured_rules.text: The Kontakta association (representing customer service and telemarketing companies) opposes a ban, accusing the Consumer Agency of overstepping authority. However, the Swedish Consumers' Association (Sveriges Konsumenter) strongly supports a total ban, noting the industry has had decades to self-regulate without success.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Stakeholder positions rather than binding legal requirements

extra_unstructured_rules.text: San Marino has implemented network-level filters to block international calls using spoofed mobile CLI (Caller Line Identification) as of August 19, 2025. Additional filters to block calls with false Italian mobile numbers became operational on November 19, 2025. These measures aim to reduce fraudulent telemarketing and vishing attacks while maintaining service continuity for legitimate roaming users.

extra_unstructured_rules.text: San Marino maintains a Registro Pubblico delle Opposizioni (Public Registry of Objections) to allow citizens to opt out of telemarketing calls. legal_restrictions.description: Telemarketing calls must not contain false or misleading statements about products or services.
Financial institutions must prevent the creation of mule accounts and will be held financially liable if negligence in their systems leads to consumer losses.
Telecom operators must actively block harmful SMS messages containing scam links. Failure to do so results in fines and legal penalties.
Mandatory reporting of suspicious accounts to the anti-money laundering office. Failure to meet requirements could lead to fines, legal penalties, and reputational damage.
Any mobile numbers used for calling must be registered to the company or an individual with ID. Call operations cannot activate hundreds of anonymous SIMs.

special_requirements: Direct marketing businesses must register with the Office of Consumer Protection Board (OCPB) before commencing operations.
Registered businesses must have at least THB 1 million in capital.
Registered businesses must place a guarantee deposit with OCPB which could be used to compensate consumers.
Businesses must maintain records of consumer consent for calls.
Foreign companies running call centers targeting Thai consumers must register with OCPB as direct marketing businesses.
PDPA applies to foreign entities handling Thai personal data.
Banks and insurers must only call individuals who have provided contact information for that purpose and keep records of consent.

rules.caller_id: International calls must be prefixed with '+' sign and specific codes by mobile operators. All numbers used must be registered SIMs.

legal_restrictions.description: Direct sales companies must deposit minimum 3 million TL in a bank account as financial guarantee.

Direct sales companies must establish a system enabling consumers to be informed and communicate requests without physical face-to-face contact through mail, catalogue, telephone, fax, email, SMS, or internet.

If communication system is not established, a three-month remediation period is granted. If violation persists, administrative fine of 1,000,000 TRY may be imposed. Fines increase annually with revaluation rate.

E-commerce intermediary service providers and service providers prohibited from using keywords consisting of registered trademarks that exclusively form the main element of domain names of third parties without prior consent in marketing and promotion activities.

special_requirements: Direct sales companies must provide mandatory information within communication system as specified by regulation

E-commerce intermediary service providers must provide technical means for data access and portability for medium, large, and very large-scale providers
Amendments to intermediary contracts require 15-day notice period (30 days for certain material changes)

sources.recent_changes: Competition Regulations, 2025 came into force on 20 September 2025, establishing the first operational competition framework in Uganda's history. Technical Committee appointed by Minister of Trade, Industry and Cooperatives to enforce regulations.

extra_unstructured_rules.text: The Ministry of Trade has 30 days to decide whether to pursue a full investigation after a complaint is lodged or inquiry opened. Complaints may be rejected if the matter is already before court or if the complainant fails to cooperate.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Procedural timeline specific to Uganda's enforcement mechanism

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Businesses must notify and seek approval for mergers or acquisitions that may substantially lessen competition. Transactions where combined turnover exceeds UGX 1 billion and target has turnover of at least UGX 500 million must be notified. Ministry retains 'call-in' power to review any deal that may harm competition, even if below thresholds.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Specific threshold values and procedural requirements for M&A in Uganda

extra_unstructured_rules.text: No comprehensive data protection law or dedicated data protection authority identified in available sources. General principles of consumer protection apply. sources.recent_changes: Automatic connection to paid services prohibition (2025); Telecommunications Regulatory Agency establishment (2025); E-commerce registration requirement (July 1, 2025); Misleading marketing law amendments (August 2025); Draft online platform protection law (March 2025)

extra_unstructured_rules.text: As of 2025, automatic connection to paid services is completely prohibited. Service connection requires two-stage process: (1) service information provided to client, (2) explicit confirmation by client via SMS, USSD, or call. This rule was introduced to prevent hidden charges and enhance market transparency. In 2024, 1,192 complaints were recorded and 683.2 million soums were refunded to subscribers.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Specific implementation rules and enforcement mechanisms not fully detailed in available sources; applies specifically to paid service subscriptions rather than general telemarketing
extra_unstructured_rules.source: Ministry of Digital Technologies; Frank.uz news (2025)

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Operators and providers must expand and develop networks in coordination with government authorities. They are allowed to lay communication cables throughout Uzbekistan either underground or along power line poles. Use of networks bypassing established protection systems is prohibited. Unauthorized use of telecom networks for transmitting international traffic is not allowed.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Infrastructure requirements rather than direct telemarketing rules; relevant to telecom service providers' operational obligations

extra_unstructured_rules.text: An independent Telecommunications Regulatory Agency is being established to replace Ministry of Digital Technologies' licensing authority. The new regulator will oversee tariffs for communication services and interconnection, define universal telecom services, establish quality standards, protect users' rights, resolve disputes between providers and operators, and manage digital labeling of telecom devices.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Regulatory structure change; relevant to enforcement authority for telemarketing compliance
extra_unstructured_rules.source: Law 'On Telecommunications' (December 27, 2024); Ministry of Justice announcement (August 2025)

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Stricter rules govern promotion of pharmaceuticals, supplements, energy drinks, alcohol, financial and insurance services, and products intended for minors. Advertising of tobacco products, gambling, and breast milk substitutes is expressly prohibited. The Anti-Monopoly Committee has authority to investigate breaches, issue binding orders to cease unlawful advertising, and require publication of corrective materials.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: Sector-specific restrictions rather than general telemarketing rules; relevant to content restrictions for certain industries
extra_unstructured_rules.source: Law 'On Advertising' No. ZRU-776 (June 7, 2022); Legal500 analysis (2025)

extra_unstructured_rules.text: Starting July 1, 2025, all companies selling goods and services online must register in Uzbekistan. This applies to businesses of all sizes - from large international marketplaces to small online stores. Previously, foreign companies could operate without registration, but this is no longer permitted. Companies already operating without registration must complete procedures with tax authorities to avoid penalties.
extra_unstructured_rules.reason_not_structured: E-commerce specific requirement; relevant to telemarketing conducted by online retailers and marketplaces
extra_unstructured_rules.source: Resolution of Cabinet of Ministers No. 885 (December 26, 2024); Settle Advisory (2025)

extra_unstructured_rules.text: The revised Law 'On Telecommunications' abolished the requirement for licenses to operate and provide data transmission network services for banks, payment systems, e-commerce platforms, and similar services. caller_id_requirements.note: Decree 91/2020 requires telemarketers to identify themselves clearly. A 'Brand Name' registration system requires companies to register a unique identifier with the Ministry of Information and Communications (MIC), which must be used in caller ID or text message headers.

frequency_limits.note: No more than one advertising call per day to the same phone number. Additionally, no more than 3 marketing SMS or emails per day to the same recipient.

legal_restrictions.description: Advertising content must not violate advertising content laws or contain prohibited topics such as fraudulent information or misinformation.
Fully automated marketing calls without prior consent are considered spam and prohibited. If using automated dialing or prerecorded messages, consent and compliance are still required.

If the call center is offering to sell goods or services, this is classified as a remote contract under the Consumer Protection Law (2023). Businesses must provide full information about seller identity, terms of sale, and right to refuse.
Foreign businesses cannot directly conduct advertising to Vietnamese consumers without going through a licensed Vietnamese advertising entity.

special_requirements: Businesses must obtain and document explicit opt-in consent before calling for promotional purposes. Pre-ticked boxes or silence do not count as consent.
Individuals have the right to withdraw consent at any time, and firms must honor such withdrawals immediately.
Call centers must not misuse or share consumer phone numbers without permission and must secure any data collected during calls.
A company is allowed to send one inquiry (often via SMS) asking for consent. If the user ignores or refuses, no further marketing contact is allowed.
Telemarketers must clearly state the company name, purpose of the call, and not engage in aggressive or misleading tactics.
Data handling policies must comply with Vietnam's Personal Data Protection (PDP) rules.
Brand name registration with the Ministry of Information and Communications (MIC) is required for entities sending advertising messages or calls.

rules.caller_id: Brand name registration with MIC required; must be displayed in caller ID or message headers
rules.exceptions: Recipient may explicitly agree to receive calls outside 8 AM - 5 PM window

max_fine.notes: KOL/KOC and business units may be fined 20-30 million VND for not clearly disclosing receipt of money for advertising or product reviews. Digital platform operators may face heavier fines of 100-200 million VND for not ensuring transparency and complete product information.

legal_restrictions.description: Telecommunications operators must have written contracts with customers before providing services. Contracts must stipulate services, prices, remedies for non-service provision, and service level agreements.
Contracts must be written in plain, clear, straightforward language. Vernacular languages and braille must be used to cater for diverse consumers including the blind.

Businesses must obtain a data controller licence from POTRAZ and appoint a Data Protection Officer within six months of regulation promulgation (September 13, 2024). Compliance deadline: March 13, 2025.
B2B telemarketing calls are subject to prohibitions on misrepresentations and false or misleading statements.
Telecommunications companies and internet service providers can face fines of up to US$5,000 for poor service delivery.

special_requirements: Written contracts must include: availability and limitation on use of service, volume, area of usage, calculation of charges and fees, billing, charges for different services, method of payment, process for suspending or disconnecting service, process for termination by consumer, personal information protection policy, warranties, customer service contact details, consumer's right to appeal to POTRAZ, and redress mechanisms.
Standard consumer contracts may be amended by licensee with POTRAZ approval. If POTRAZ does not respond within 30 days to amendment request, amendment is deemed approved.
All licensed operators must file standard customer service agreements with POTRAZ for approval.

Consumers have rights to: choice, disclosure, access to high quality service, accurate bills, privacy, protection against market abuse, responsive regulatory authority, consumer education, safety, complaint and redress, and ability to end or change contract.

max_fine.notes: Telecommunications companies and ISPs can face fines up to US$5,000 for poor service delivery. Additional penalties may apply under data protection regulations.
